title: Student accused of sex attacks on four women insists he is a 'Christian'
text:
Sam Ringer is accused of a string of sex attacks while he was a student at the University of Worcester

A university student accused of a string of sex attacks has told a court he is a 'bit of a player' but denies wrongdoing, insisting he was 'brought up a Christian'.

Sam Ringer, 20, is on trial accused of two rapes and three sexual assaults over allegations made when he was a University of Worcester student.

Ringer, a former sports and exercise science student and basketball player, denies the allegations, insisting any sex was consensual.

Hereford Crown Court heard four women have accused Ringer, of Ilkeston, Derbyshire, of either raping them or sexually assaulting them after nights out in 2017 and 2018.

The first allegation relates to an incident after Ringer had been to the Bushwackers nightclub in 2017.

A woman claimed he attacked her in a flat in the city, but Ringer told the court: 'She asked me to get into bed so I did.'

He previously told police the sex was 'perfectly consensual' and the woman, not him, locked a door to the room.

Ringer is also accused of attacks on two women who he walked home after dumping his girlfriend in 2018.

The final allegation refers to an sexual assault in July 2018.

He is accused of carrying out sex attacks on women after nights out in the city

When asked by police about his reputation at the university and he said: 'Probably a bit of a player.

But he added: 'Being a Christian I knew it wasn't right.'

Speaking of the complainants, he told officers: 'It feels like they're all trying to get something back on me.'

At his trial, Ringer told the jury he was the grandson of a vicar and 'brought up a Christian' and attended the university church.

He had to leave university after the allegations came to light and now lives with his parents in Ilkeston.

He denies the charges. The trial continues.
